message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about light pollution. When there are more inhabited buildings in a space, there tends to be more light pollution, making it more difficult to see stars in the sky. Option (A) is incorrect because brighter city lights actually make stars less visible. Option (C) is a subjective statement and not related to astronomical observations. Option (D) is not necessarily true because light pollution can make stars less visible.

This question requires an understanding of light pollution. When there are a greater number of inhabited buildings in a space, there tends to be more artificial light and therefore more light pollution. This can make it more difficult to see stars in the sky, resulting in fewer visible stars. Option (A) is incorrect because the brightness of stars is not directly related to the number of inhabited buildings. Option (C) is a subjective opinion and not related to light pollution. Option (D) is also incorrect because the number of stars in the sky is not directly related to the number of inhabited buildings.

This question requires an understanding of light pollution and its effect on star visibility. The more inhabited buildings there are in a space, the more artificial light pollution there is. This light pollution can obscure the visibility of stars, making fewer stars visible in the sky. Option (A) is incorrect because the brightness of stars is determined by their intrinsic luminosity, not the number of inhabited buildings. Option (C) is a subjective statement and not related to the phenomenon of star visibility. Option (D) is incorrect because the number of stars in the sky is not directly affected by the number of inhabited buildings.
